title: Naming Nature
abstractText:
The project is a cross- disciplinary collabroation between three of the UKs top research organisations and an establishment with an excellent track record in educating schools and the general public.

Sir Alister Hardy Foundation for Ocean Science (SAHFOS), Plymouth Marine Laboratory (PML), University of Plymouth (UoP) and the Plymouth City Museum and Art Gallery will present an interactive science event during National Science and Engineering Week (NSEW) 2008.  'Naming Nature'  is aimed at encouraging a better understanding of ecology, taxonomy and the environment.

The weeklong activities will run from 10-14 March 2009 and will be held at Plymouth City Museum and Art Gallery, Plymouth.  Based on our 2008 evaluations it is hoped that the event will attract approximately 600 school children and members of the general public. Our target audience is 8-13 year olds but the workshop materials which highlight natural history, ecology and the environment will be suitable for all age groups.

The organisations involved in the project will present 5 science workshops covering marine organisms, plants, insects, birds, fossils and evolution and the future of taxonomy. Visitors will have the opportunity to:

  • learn why it is important to classify living and non living organisms
  • why scientific names are Latin or Greek
  • appreciate how taxonomy provides us with information about evolution and the planet's biodiversity
  • how it enables us to help conserve species and habitat diversity for future generations
  • design their own 'alien' organism and give it a scientific name to win a prize.
